newsitem.title: USA: China sugar imports seen falling in 96/97 - attache.
newsitem.headline: China sugar imports seen falling in 96/97 - attache.

text.p: China's legal imports of sugar will drop to 800,000 tonnes in the 1996/97 marketing year, and domestic stocks will be reduced by 500,000 tonnes during the same period, according to a U.S. agricultural attache report made public on Thursday.
In a report prepared by the American Embassy in Beijing, analysts said China had "effectively cracked down" on smuggling but was still suffering the effects of smuggling from two years earlier.
"Given rapid growth in consumption, China will most likely resume imports of sugar in marketing year 1997/98," the report stated.

The report also reiterated a U.S. Agriculture Department forecast that China would increase its sugar production to 7.175 million tonnes in 1997/98. But China's goal of increasing production to 10 million tonnes by 2000 and 13 million tonnes by 2010 "is unattainable over the short-term" because China's production of sugarcane is shifting to increasingly marginal land.

Although official Chinese estimates place per capita sugar consumption at 6.2 kilograms, the attache report estimated that it is 6.6 kilograms per capita and rising. The number was still low compared to per capita consumption in other countries such as Japan (18.4 kg), South Korea (21.6 kg) and the United States (29.7 kg).

China's total annual consumption was estimated at 8.125 million tonnes in 1996/97 and 8.21 million tonnes in 1997/98, with the increase driven by population growth and increased use in the processed food and soft drink industries, the report said.

"The government of China successfully cracked down on smuggling of sugar in 1996, with smuggling dropping off to approximately 100-200,000 tonnes. However, refineries are still suffering financial difficulties resulting from low domestic prices for sugar," the report said.
Agricultural attache reports are not official USDA data.
